title: What are some differences and similarities between Plato and Descartes? - Quora

response.answer_text: Both were dualists, but they were dualists of very different sorts. Plato’s dualism is epistemological in motivation, and only becomes metaphysical by extension. It is a dualism between mere opinion - shadows on a cave wall — on the one hand, and certain knowledge — the Forms seen in the sunlight of the supreme Form, the Good — on the other. Descartes’s dualism is metaphysical in motivation. Or, perhaps, physical. It is focused on the distinction between the world of mind and the world of matter or body. Mind is conceived of entirely as the source of thoughts — body is conceived of entirely as the taking up of space — it becomes difficult to explain how the two can even have a connection. From this difference in the motivation of their dualisms come other differences. I’ll just mention the most obvious. Descartes believes that we CAN have reliable knowledge of the physical world. We can know that chunks of matter push each other around, for example, because one chunk will occupy a patch of space to the exclusion of another chunk. Plato believed on the other hand that trying to acquire reliable knowledge of the physical world is a fool’s game — the shadows on the cave wall are subjects merely of opinion, NOT of knowledge.
